issue.title: Add man page
issue.body:
It would be nice to autogenerate a man page which not only shows all of the help information but also includes detailed information on how to write glitter formats.  That way, typing `man glit` can be a substitute for coming to the README on this repo.

However, it is unclear at this time how much work is required to generate a man page and how many of the things mentioned here are actually publicly useable:

- [cli working group's tracking issue](https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/cli-wg/issues/38)
- [ripgrep's man file generation](https://github.com/BurntSushi/ripgrep/blob/8892bf648cfec111e6e7ddd9f30e932b0371db68/build.rs#L66)
- [previous work on generating man pages](https://github.com/clap-rs/clap/issues/552)

Features I would like include:

- [ ] include help information generated from structop
- [ ] additional documentation for glitter formats
  - [ ] test all example formats in the man page against glitter

commits.message: Remove redundant documentation

issue.title: Add support for arbitrary separators
issue.body:
For example, if I wanted to deliniate different aspects of my format with spaces so that I could have:

```
branch@origin/branch M1?2 {@1}
```

If there are no changes to the index or the working tree, then two spaces would appear between the branch information and the stash information:

```
branch@origin/branch  {@1}
```

Or if I wanted to separate the working tree from the staging index with a bar and the ahead/behind information with a comma like so:

```
branch@origin/branch ahead 1, behind 2 [M1|R2]
```

There is currently no way supported by glitter to do so.  Thus, I could explore adding a new expression type specifically for this purpose which uses the write_queue in the interpreter to queue separator characters to be written only when the expression which follows outputs anything and thus drains the queue.

I recommend supporting the following limited set of separator characters:

- "`,`"
- "`|`"
- "` `"

They could be written in the format exactly like so:

```
#y(#g*('~')'/C/u/glitter') [#c(#*(b)B(#~('@'{+(#g('↿')), -(#r('⇃'))})))] {{#g(MARD)|#r(maud)}} \(\h(#m('@')))'\n''➟'' '
```

Because the separators need special knowledge about items being written both before _and_ after they appear, they would need to handled in the tree level interpreter function.

payload.description: Display git status information in your shell prompt

release.name: Release 0.3.0
release.body:
# Changes

- New and simplified syntax (#36)
    - named expressions do not have an leading backslash except for `\'`; for example, `\b` becomes `b`
    - group expressions also do not have a leading backslash except for `\()` to disambiguate from prefixes
- Glitter now supports separators, a form of intelligent "whitespace" (#35)
- Add error messages for any parse errors (#36)
    - Error messages are descriptive and point directly to the source of the error: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14112725/65543129-87905580-dede-11e9-887a-dfc29bd651b0.png)

This means that all existing users will need to re-write their formats; however, the error messages should be more helpful when doing so.

commits.message: Remove redundant and outdated documentation from lib
Version bump 0.3.0!
Fix rendering error in README
Fix rendering error in README

Remove backslashes from most parts of language

Backslashes were added to accomodate multi-character named args,
but since I have no intention of adding them anymore, they are now
redundant and just make glitter harder to use.

Additionally, remove the `\\` command which would print a literal
backslash, as '\' does the same thing, meaning the only required
escape is the `\'` command.  All other characters can be added with
literals like '#' for example.

The only expression that still requires a backslash is the \() group
to avoid ambiguity with the other contexts of (), but this means that
the other group expressions [],<>,{}, now can be just written as is
with matching automatically functioning for them without annoying
backslashes.

Simplify AST for group expressions

Remove unecessary strings and replace them with an enum to specify
group expression types.

Previously, these values were a string to allow for arbitrary
groups which surrounded contents with any desired delimiters.
This is no longer planned or considered a priority.

Begin migration to nom 5

Remove all parser code, re-implementing named expressions under
new system.

Upgrade parser and simplify language

Remove unecessary vectors from the AST, opting to use the newly
structured CompleteStyle (formerly StyleContext) rather than a
vector of styles.  This is lossy, but more efficient.

Now, styles are written like so:

    #g_*('test')

As opposed to the old form:

    #g;_;*('test')

Further, in the upgrade to nom 5, switch from macro-based to
function/closure based implementation.  Work is still necessary to
properly propagate errors out of the parser and display them to
the user in a friendly way.
Update README to reflect syntax changes

Remove unecessary clone in interpreter

Cloning every tree is unecessary, and this improvement has improved
performance by 50-85% across the board

Update style benchmarks

Previous benchmark measured performance concerns which are now
irrelevant because it performs in constant time relative to the
benchmark, by moving work that was done in the benchmark to work
being done before it even runs.

Add separator support

Separators can appear between expressions and will intelligently
apper or not appear depending on whether the previous and follwing
separators are drawn.  For example:

    "[#g(MARD)|#r(mard)]"

The "|" character is a separator and will only appear if an item
from the "MARD" group and the "mard" group _both_ appear, then the
"|" will print.  Any number of separators can be chained!  This
allows for glitter to avoid annoying sequences of literals in many
cases, and makes it much more natural to space out different parts
of the prompt.

Separators will appear if _any_ non-separator expression in the
tree was written before, but separators only apper _between_ the
expected expressions.  For example:

    "b@B 'test'"

If b _and_ B print, then the @ will print.  If only b prints, the
space will still appear between b and test.  This should be the
most intuitive behaviour.
Remove typo from install instructions

Update README examples with separators

Makes them FAR shorter and much more readable; I have also used a
format which is far easier to understand for beginners as it
closely matches `git status -sb` while still being relatively
compact.
Update glit example image
Use local demo image rather than GitHub's

Ensure separators properly clean up at end of tree

This ensures that the separators don't leak onto parent trees;
before:

    [...b...]B

produces:

    [master]...origin/master

after:

    [...b...]B

produces:

    [master]origin/master

Refactor interpreter simplifying code

Remove many unused arguments and pointless return of the style
Update examples and guide in README for separators

Parse from string instead of bytes

Allows for much cleaner handling of the 'string' expression

Implement preliminary error system

Error system still produces really strange errors when
unrecognized characters appear inside of a parser; for example,

   "o" -> unrecognized

is properly recognized as unrecognized; however, if I surround it
with any expression with delimiters, I get an error like so:

   "{o}" -> missing delimitor '}'
Fix rendering error in table on github

Add error messages to parser

Getting the error messages I wanted required using custom
combinators; however, that was not much of a problem as nom is
shockingly easy to extend and use!

Error messages required changing some things around, but most of
the system relies on cleverly placed context combinators and
liberal use of map_err and map_fail to create more specific errors
when necessary.

Ensure separators are properly cleared

Separators were not properly cleared between expressions, which
results in separators accumulating in unexpected ways.

pull_request.title: Update glitter syntax
pull_request.body:
I have had a few old (#15) and new (#35) ideas for simplifying glitter formats and making them far nicer to write.  The combination of these ideas makes writing formats _far_ more ergonomic compared to before.

For even just a very trivial format, the old glitter syntax would look like so:

```
\b\B('..')
```

Which now can be written

```
b..B
```
Formats  map much more directly to their result, and are thus far easier to read and work with.  The limitation is that now each expression can be only a single character to avoid ambiguity, but the benefit is that the formats are _far_ easier to read!  It's unlikely that glitter will need to support more than 26*2 types of git metadata anyway, so this limitation is easy to accept.

Separators also add support for formats which were impossible before in an unobtrusive way:

| Example 1                                                       |
|-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| ![example-1]                                                    |
|`glit "[#c*(b)@#c(B):{+,-} \| #~(#g(MARD):#r(maud):h('@'))]"`|

| Example 2 |
|----------------|
| ![example-2]  |
| `glit "#g*(b)..#r(B)[+('↑')-('↓'), #~(#g(MARD):#r(maud)), h(#m('@'))]"` |

- [x] Rewrite parser to use latest nom
- [x] Add separators to the parser and interpreter
    - [ ] add tests and benchmarks
- [ ] Produce more useful errors when a format fails to parse
- [x] Update guides and documentation
- [ ] Finalize release 0.3.0!

[example-1]: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14112725/65245452-a8117780-daba-11e9-90e4-8407cfc34b56.png
[example-2]: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14112725/65246285-39cdb480-dabc-11e9-83b2-2a6250eb1b74.png

commits.message: Update to Criterion 0.3

Add parser benchmark tests

Benchmarks currently do not cover format expressions because I am
lazy.

Ensure separators are properly cleared

Separators were not properly cleared between expressions, which
results in separators accumulating in unexpected ways.

Add color to error messages

Requires changes to the API in order to allow choosing whether to
print with color as fmt::Display is fairly rigid (to my knowledge)
with respect to formatting options.

payload.description: Display git status information in your shell prompt

commits.message:
Add error messages to parser

Getting the error messages I wanted required using custom
combinators; however, that was not much of a problem as nom is
shockingly easy to extend and use!

Error messages required changing some things around, but most of
the system relies on cleverly placed context combinators and
liberal use of map_err and map_fail to create more specific errors
when necessary.

commits.message: Remove typo from install instructions

Update README examples with separators

Makes them FAR shorter and much more readable; I have also used a
format which is far easier to understand for beginners as it
closely matches `git status -sb` while still being relatively
compact.

Add separator support

Separators can appear between expressions and will intelligently
apper or not appear depending on whether the previous and follwing
separators are drawn.  For example:

    "[#g(MARD)|#r(mard)]"

The "|" character is a separator and will only appear if an item
from the "MARD" group and the "mard" group _both_ appear, then the
"|" will print.  Any number of separators can be chained!  This
allows for glitter to avoid annoying sequences of literals in many
cases, and makes it much more natural to space out different parts
of the prompt.

Separators will appear if _any_ non-separator expression in the
tree was written before, but separators only apper _between_ the
expected expressions.  For example:

    "b@B 'test'"

If b _and_ B print, then the @ will print.  If only b prints, the
space will still appear between b and test.  This should be the
most intuitive behaviour.

issue.title: Add support for arbitrary separators
issue.body:
For example, if I wanted to deliniate different aspects of my format with spaces so that I could have:

```
branch@origin/branch M1?2 {@1}
```

If there are no changes to the index or the working tree, then two spaces would appear between the branch information and the stash information:

```
branch@origin/branch  {@1}
```

Or if I wanted to separate the working tree from the staging index with a bar and the ahead/behind information with a comma like so:

```
branch@origin/branch ahead 1, behind 2 [M1|R2]
```

There is currently no way supported by glitter to do so.  Thus, I could explore adding a new expression type specifically for this purpose which uses the write_queue in the interpreter to queue separator characters to be written only when the expression which follows outputs anything and thus drains the queue.

I recommend supporting the following limited set of separator characters:

- "`,`"
- "`|`"
- "` `"

They could be written in the format exactly like so:

```
#y(#g*('~')'/C/u/glitter') [#c(#*(b)B(#~('@'{+(#g('↿')), -(#r('⇃'))})))] {{#g(MARD)|#r(maud)}} \(\h(#m('@')))'\n''➟'' '
```

Because the separators need special knowledge about items being written both before _and_ after they appear, they would need to handled in the tree level interpreter function.
